metadata.case_name: Writ Petitions Nos. 76, 217 to 228 of 1960 (and connected petitions)

facts.text: Petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental right to carry on business of motor transport in West Godavari District by issuance of writs to quash schemes approved by Government of Andhra Pradesh on March 21, 1960.

Chief Executive Officer, Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation published seven proposals dated December 7, 1959, in Andhra Pradesh Gazette dated December 17, 1959, for nationalization of road transport in different parts of West Godavari District under s. 68C of Motor Vehicles Act.
More than 3000 objections received against the schemes.

Government issued notices to objectors and representatives of Transport Corporation for hearings on March 10, 11 and 12, 1960; 200 objectors present, most represented by Advocates; Transport Corporation represented by Chief Executive Officer and legal advisers.

Minister in charge of transport held enquiry, considered conflicting arguments, gave findings, rejected all objections but one, approved schemes with slight modification; schemes directed to be put in force from different dates.
Schemes signed by Shri Guru Pershad, Chief Executive Officer, Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation.
In certain schemes, number of vehicles not specified per route but bracketed for two or more routes; Minister directed modification to indicate separately; approved schemes published March 21, 1960.
Schemes include clause: 'The frequency of services on any of the notified routes or within any notified area shall, if necessary, be varied having regard to the traffic needs during any period.'
Schemes include new routes: Eluru to Kovvur, and Nidadavol to Jeelugumilli.

Sub-committee consisting of Ministers, Secretaries and officers, presided by Minister for transport, decided on January 28, 1960, to take over bus services in West Godavari and Guntur Districts before end of year.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of Ch. IVA of Motor Vehicles Act are ultra vires Parliament's powers as within exclusive State field.
Whether Ch. IVA infringes Art. 19(1)(g) and not saved by Art. 19(6).
Whether order confirming schemes vitiated by bias.
Whether seven schemes are components of one scheme to circumvent Srinivasa Reddy judgment.
Whether schemes void as prepared/published by Chief Executive Officer not authorized under s.13 Road Transport Corporations Act.
Whether schemes violate r.4 Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Rules by not specifying vehicles per route.
Whether r.5 Rules and clause on varying frequency inconsistent with Act.
Whether schemes illegal for including new routes.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Ch. IVA ultra vires Parliament as within exclusive State legislative field.
Ch. IVA infringes Art. 19(1)(g), not saved by Art. 19(6) as permits partial exclusion within same class.
Ch. IVA violates Art. 14 by arbitrary discrimination between State Corporation and private operators.
Government order vitiated by bias; Government controls Corporation, sub-committee predetermined issue.
Seven schemes are parts of one scheme to circumvent Srinivasa Reddy v. State of Mysore.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Srinivasa Reddy v. State of Mysore (1960) 2 SCR 130

petitioner_arguments.text: Schemes void as published by Chief Executive Officer not authorized under s.13 Road Transport Corporations Act.
Schemes violate r.4 by not giving vehicles per route; Minister's modification insufficient.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Rules r.4

petitioner_arguments.text: R.5 and frequency clause inconsistent with s.68E, permit modification without procedure.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Motor Vehicles Act s.68E; Rules r.5

petitioner_arguments.text: Schemes illegal for including new routes; s.68C only for existing routes.

respondent_arguments.text: Schemes as approved by Minister sustained in entirety.
Corporation authorized Chief Executive Officer under s.12(c) Road Transport Corporations Act to publish schemes as day-to-day administration.
Each of seven schemes capable of implementation all at once; separate and independent.
Frequency clause only for emergencies per traffic needs.

court_reasoning.text: Ch. IVA competently enacted by Parliament under entry 21 read with 35 Concurrent List; follows H.C. Narayanappa.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by Parliament.

court_reasoning.text: Ch. IVA saved by Art. 19(6)(ii); wide terms permit exclusion complete or partial of citizens in any area/route/service; s.68C within limits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No limitations on State's power to confer monopoly in respect of area, person or persons.

court_reasoning.text: Classification between State Undertaking and private operators reasonable, has nexus to object of efficient public service; procedure prevents arbitrariness; follows Saghir Ahmad.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification has reasonable nexus to object; machinery ensures no arbitrary power.

court_reasoning.text: No official or personal bias; Government discharges statutory function; sub-committee policy decision not predetermination; follows Gullapalli Nageswara Rao and Narayanappa.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unless reliable evidence of bias, decision not liable to challenge merely because authority is limb of Government.

court_reasoning.text: Seven schemes separate and independent, each implementable in entirety from different dates; not to circumvent Srinivasa Reddy which prevents piecemeal within single scheme.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No objection to multiple schemes or phased programme across schemes.

court_reasoning.text: Chief Executive Officer authorized under s.12(c) for day-to-day administration; publication ministerial act after Corporation decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presume Corporation authenticated decision; CEO published mechanically.

court_reasoning.text: Approved schemes as modified contain vehicles per route per r.4(ii); published by Government.
R.5 and frequency clause permit substantial modification without s.68E procedure; rule void; clause severable and deleted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Variation amounts to modification requiring full procedure.

court_reasoning.text: S.68C empowers schemes for any area/route including new routes; 'route' includes proposed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No inherent inconsistency; new route is area limited to route.

holdings.text: Ch. IVA does not infringe Art. 19(1)(g), saved by Art. 19(6).
Ch. IVA does not violate Art. 14.
Seven schemes valid, not circumventing prior judgment.
Chief Executive Officer empowered to publish schemes.
Schemes comply with r.4 after modification.
Frequency clause void and severable; schemes otherwise valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.C. Narayanappa v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Ch. IVA competently enacted by Parliament; no bias if acts judicially.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Ch. IVA constitutional; procedure prevents arbitrariness; no bias.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
Srinivasa Reddy v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Schemes must be implementable all at once; not violated by multiple schemes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Saghir Ahmad v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Classification for State monopoly rational under Art. 14.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers schemes for nationalization; procedure for objections/hearing; applied and upheld except frequency variation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights enforcement; Ch. IVA saved thereunder.

statutes_cited.name: Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorizes CEO to publish schemes as administrative act.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Particulars in schemes; r.5 void for permitting unprocedural modification.

outcome.summary: Petitions dismissed; frequency clause in schemes directed to be deleted as severable and void; schemes otherwise upheld; petitions fail in other respects.
outcome.relief_granted: Delete clause on varying frequency of services.

key_quotes.text: "We are therefore of the view that Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Article 19(6) is only a saving provision and the law made empowering the State to carry on a business is secured from attack on the ground of infringement of the fundamental rights of a citizen to the extent it does not exceed the limits of the scope of the said provision."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The scheme, before it is finalised, is subjected to public gaze and scrutiny and the validity and appropriateness of the provisions are tested by a quasi-judicial process."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains procedure safeguarding against arbitrariness under Art. 14.

key_quotes.text: "This rule is void and, therefore, the said notification was illegally inserted in the schemes. But on that ground... we cannot hold that the schemes are void. The notification is easily severable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
